articles.headline: Los Angeles and San Diego Schools to Go Online-Only in the Fall
articles.snippet: California’s two largest districts made the joint call amid a White House push to get children back into classrooms.
articles.abstract: California’s two largest districts made the joint call amid a White House push to get children back into classrooms.
articles.lead_paragraph: SACRAMENTO — California’s two largest public school districts said on Monday that instruction would be online-only in the fall, in the latest sign that school administrators are increasingly unwilling to risk crowding students back into classrooms until the coronavirus is fully under control.
articles.byline: By Shawn Hubler and Dana Goldstein

articles.headline: Hong Kong Disneyland to Close Again, Days After Disney World Reopens
articles.snippet: The park is the smallest in Disney’s portfolio and is shutting down again to comply with a government-mandated rollback of public activities because of the coronavirus.
articles.abstract: The park is the smallest in Disney’s portfolio and is shutting down again to comply with a government-mandated rollback of public activities because of the coronavirus.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hong Kong Disneyland will close again on Wednesday to comply with a government-directed rollback of public activities in the region after an increase in coronavirus infections, the Walt Disney Company said on Monday. Disney called the closing of the theme park “temporary” and said its resort hotels at the Lantau Island complex would remain open.

articles.headline: Monthly U.S. Budget Deficit Soared to Record $864 Billion in June
articles.snippet: The shortfall was nearly as large as the entire 2019 deficit as spending on virus-related efforts outpaced revenues.
articles.abstract: The shortfall was nearly as large as the entire 2019 deficit as spending on virus-related efforts outpaced revenues.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States budget deficit grew to a record $864 billion for June as the federal government pumped huge sums of money into the economy to prop up workers and businesses affected by the coronavirus, the Treasury Department said on Monday, an amount that is expected to grow as a surge in cases portends prolonged economic pain.
articles.byline: By Alan Rappeport and Jim Tankersley

articles.headline: These Are the Deutsche Bank Executives Responsible for Serving Jeffrey Epstein
articles.snippet: When New York regulators punished the bank for its work with Mr. Epstein, no individuals were named. The Times identified them.
articles.abstract: When New York regulators punished the bank for its work with Mr. Epstein, no individuals were named. The Times identified them.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jeffrey Epstein, the sex criminal and financier, didn’t act alone. Now we know in vivid detail who some of his financial enablers were: executives and bankers at Deutsche Bank.

articles.headline: Headed to the Convention? Not I, More Republicans Are Saying
articles.snippet: “Everybody just assumes no one is going,” said one House member wary of the virus risks. But other delegates dismissed the health threat and said it was an honor to help nominate President Trump.
articles.abstract: “Everybody just assumes no one is going,” said one House member wary of the virus risks. But other delegates dismissed the health threat and said it was an honor to help nominate President Trump.
articles.lead_paragraph: [Update: Trump abruptly cancels Republican Convention in Jacksonville.]
articles.byline: By Reid J. Epstein, Nicholas Fandos and Patricia Mazzei

articles.headline: As Europe’s Economies Reopen, Consumers Go on a Spending Spree
articles.snippet: Supported by government furlough programs, people freed from lockdowns are opening their wallets at a record pace. The virus will determine how long that lasts.
articles.abstract: Supported by government furlough programs, people freed from lockdowns are opening their wallets at a record pace. The virus will determine how long that lasts.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — Clémentine Sebert buzzed through an Ikea furniture store during her lunch break, filling her cart with decorative cushions, a new nightstand, lamps and a small rug. After being cooped up for two months during France’s coronavirus quarantine, she was back to work at the firm where she is a legal counselor — and ready to spend.

articles.headline: I Went Home to Texas to Cover the Virus. Then My Family Got It.
articles.snippet: Edgar Sandoval knew he was well prepared to report on the spread of the coronavirus on the Texas-Mexico border. He was going home. Little did he know exactly what he would find.
articles.abstract: Edgar Sandoval knew he was well prepared to report on the spread of the coronavirus on the Texas-Mexico border. He was going home. Little did he know exactly what he would find.
articles.lead_paragraph: McALLEN, Texas — There were many reasons for a special level of alarm when the coronavirus swept out of Texas’ biggest cities in recent weeks and arrived with force in the Rio Grande Valley.

articles.headline: Want More Diversity? Some Experts Say Reward C.E.O.s for It
articles.snippet: Only a small number of large companies have tied executive compensation to goals for hiring and promotion of workers from underrepresented groups.
articles.abstract: Only a small number of large companies have tied executive compensation to goals for hiring and promotion of workers from underrepresented groups.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Charles E. Jones, the chief executive of a large Ohio-based utility, realized that his senior executives weren’t fully behind his push to hire and promote people of color and women, he decided to do something to get their attention.

articles.headline: U.K. Bars Huawei for 5G as Tech Battle Between China and the West Escalates
articles.snippet: Banning the use of the Chinese tech giant’s equipment in high-speed wireless infrastructure is a major reversal by Prime Minister Boris Johnson — and a big victory for the Trump administration.
articles.abstract: Banning the use of the Chinese tech giant’s equipment in high-speed wireless infrastructure is a major reversal by Prime Minister Boris Johnson — and a big victory for the Trump administration.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Britain announced on Tuesday that it would ban equipment from the Chinese technology giant Huawei from the country’s high-speed wireless network, a victory for the Trump administration that escalates the battle between Western powers and China over critical technology.
articles.byline: By Adam Satariano, Stephen Castle and David E. Sanger
